div.l: Be goddis sale it shal non othyr be
Thys Iohn answerd aleyn auyse the
The myllere is a perlous man he seyde
And yf that he out of hys slepe abreyde
He myght do vs bathe a velony
Aleyn answerd I counte hym not a flye
And vp he rist and by the wenche he creep
Thys wenche lay vpright and fast sleep
Tyl he so ny was or she myght aspye
That it had be to late for to crye
And shortly for to telle they were attone
Now pley Aleyn for I wyl speke of Iohn
Thys Iohn lieth stylle a furlongwey or two
And to hym self he made routhe and woo
Allas quod he this is a wickyd Iape
Now may I say that I is but an ape
Yet hath my felow somwhat for hys harm
He hath the Myllars doughter in hys arme
He auntrid hym and hath hys nedis spedde
And I ly as a draf sak in my bedde
And whan this Iape is told anothyr day
I shal be hold a daffe a cokenay
I wyl a ryse and auntre it be my feyth
Vnhardy is vnsely thus men seyth
And vp he roos and softly he went
Vnto the cradyl and in hys arm it hent
And bare it softe vnto hys beddis feet
Sone aftyr the wyf hyr rowtyng leet
And gan awake and wente her out to pysse
And cam ayen and gan hyr cradyl mysse
And gropid here ⁊and there but she fond non
Allas quod she I hadde almost mysgon
I hadde almost goon to the clerkis bed
Ey benedicite than hadde I foule sped
And forth she goth tyl she the cradyl fond
She gropyth alwey ferther wyth her hond
And fond þᵉ bed ⁊and thoughte nought but good
By cause that the cradyl by it stood
